The second option, 'apparatus', refers to a complex piece of equipment or machinery, making it a suitable choice.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. Hence, the answer is B: apparatus.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Rationales: 1. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Traders work on the floor of the stock what? Choices:  A: building B: hallway C: table D: exchange E: office<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. Trader<n><n>### Response 2:<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Examine the following sentence and identify the verb.<n><n>### In the story, the author’s mother was  to him.<n><n>### The answer choice is:<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>The underlined word, "took an interest in," is actually the verb in this sentence. Choices:  A. that you don’t need to do<n>B. to just do what I say, and then<n>C. just what to do<n>D. why you should do<n>E: never to do<n>Rationales:<n>1.A. “that” is used to indicate a noun/noun phrase that supports the main clause of the sentence.<n>2.B. “because” is needed before “I say”.<n>3.C. “just” is incorrectly used because “you don’t need to” is necessary to the sentence. <n>4.D. “why” would be correct if followed by a statement to indicate the reason or cause why one should do what is “told”.<n>5.E. “never” is not needed. The sentence states the problem, but doesn’t provide enough information to complete it. The sentence “I’m tired of my [person] ….” could be followed by A, B, C or D.<n>6.Therefore B is the correct answer.<n><n>### Solution<n>1.A. that you don’<n>	2.B. to just do<n>	3.C. just what to<n>	4.D. why you should<n>	5.E. never to<n><n>### Input B:<n>“That’s just not the way to do it,” the woman complained.<n>Choices: <n>A: to just find <n>B: not find<n>C: just saying<n>D: to find out<n>E: that say <n>Rationales:  <n>1. Choices:  A: satisfied B: unnecessary C: luxury D: sufficient E: extra<n><n>### Response:		<n>The third choice, "luxury", refers to a situation or occurrence that is not necessary but pleasant or enjoyable. In this context, luxury could also refer to something that you can "afford to be without" but it is not necessarily the correct answer as it doesn’t necessarily mean that you don’t "need" something.<n><n>### Answer: B: unnecessary<n><n>### Input:"It's the little things that make life a little better." Explain how they're supposed to be "better".<n><n>### Response:"The little things" in the quotation refers to things that are often overlooked or taken for granted. These things may be simple and unremarkable, but they can still significantly improve a person's life or make it more enjoyable. For example, a warm smile from a stranger or a sunny day can be "better" than a difficult situation or a rainy day.

Choices:  A. early B. after early C. later D. anytime E. at specific time<n>Rationales:<n><n>Input:The dog can sit down anywhere in the house. Choices:   A. in the corner of the porch B. on the side porch C. in the middle of the porch D. in the corner of porch E. in the center of the porch<n>Rationales:     1. In the sentence, the word anywhere refers to the fact that dog can sit down anywhere (in any location) in the house. Anywhere is a place where a dog can sit. 2. We are looking for a location, so we can immediately discard option A: in the corner of the  porch. 3. Option B: in the side porch can be used to express a location or a direction. So, we need to eliminate the location aspect of it. This option doesn’t answer the question. 4. Looking at option C: in the middle of the  porch, we can eliminate it. Middle can refer to a particular point or location. So, we don’t know if this option includes the center of the porce or the middle of the porce, as in middle part of the porce. Hence, we need to eliminate option too. 5. Looking at option D. in the corner in the porch, corner could be referring to any corner of the porch. So, because we cannot be sure as to which corner is referred to, we need to eliminate this option as well. 6. The last option E. in the center  of the porch refers to the center or middle of the porch.  This is the correct answer as it only describes a location.  Answer :The dog can sit down in the center of the  porch    <n><n>### Instruct:Answer the following multiple - choice question.<n><n><n>### Demstotion: <n><n>### Question:<n>Do you want me to take my sweater from __________ my desk? Choices:  B: very good C: It is great D: It's okay E: It was terrible F: It was terrific G: it was a hit<n><n>### Demosation :<n>1. "How was" is an interrogative- "it was terrible" is a statement - so the statement is incorrect<n>2. "It was terrible" and "It's okay" are both statements<n><n>### Response :<n>* "F: It's a hit." and "G: It's a great success." are statements.<n><n>### Questions<n>Input: What do you have for lunch, Sam? Choices:  C: A: Dinners B: pizza C: sushi D: spaghetti E: ham sandwich <n><n>### Response<n>* "What do you... for lunch" is passive voice - it's a suggestion<n><n>### Demotion :(<n>* We don't know if Sam actually likes lunch, so "it was" is incorrect<n><n>### Input :<n>* "What time is it" should be in present perfect, because at the time, it was not in the past<n><n>### Response :(<n>* If Sam said "It's not so late," it would be correct grammar and mean the same thing<n><n># Input : <n>In what conditions are children entitled to child support payments?<n><n>  - from before the child was born<n>  - after the child was born<n>- <n> <n>Input : <n>It isn't good to have a car if you can't drive it.<n><n>  - to have a car isn't good<n>  - if you can't driving it isn't good<n>- <n> 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The sentence asks for a suitable noun to describe the complexity of the machine. <n>2. The first option, 'box', is not suitable because although a box could possibly contain complex things, it is not complex in itself.<n>3. The second option, 'apparatus', refers to a complex piece of equipment or machinery, making it a suitable choice.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. Hence, the answer is B: apparatus.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Rationales: 1. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Why does she sing so much? Choices:  A: insane B: annoy people around C: enjoy D: inhale E: had good voice<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>E. had good voice<n><n>\<n>The term'sing' in the question doesn’t always suggest an ability to perform singing skillfully, which is the implication behind 'enjoy' and 'have a good voice' as given in the options. <n>Hence, the correct answer is option E, 'had good voice'.<n><n>### Input:(5×3=15) The company is planning for 15 per cent increase in sales. In the last meeting, Mr Manish asked 6 questions and received 10 answers <n>Choose ONE of the statements and rewrite the question.<n>1. _______ (Rewrite the first 2 lines) Choices: The company is planning for increase in sales. In the last meeting, <n>Mr Manish asked and received <n><n>### Response:(7×2=14)<n>There are four incorrect statements.<n>1) 6 question are received from 10 answers.<n>2) The result is the double than the previous meeting.<n>3) The company is planning that they sold a little low to increase more then 15 percent in sales.<n>4) The Mr. Manish is looking forward for more than 10 questions in next meeting.<n><n>#### Rationale Statement 1 : "The company is planning for increase of 15 per cent in sales"(first line), isn't true, because, in a company 15 per cent could still be negative<n><n>#### Rationale No 2: "In the last meeting, Mr. Manish asked 6 question and received 10 answer"(first line), implies, 6 questions could be different than 10 answer because, the count of asking questions doesn't have relation with answer.<n>Now, in the second line "The company is planning that they have sold little low to increase more than 15 per cent of sales" The word which is used is "that", implies, they planning based on previous year result, so, it does not match with the first line, also, "to increase more than 10 percent of sales" shows, the result is the double of previous year.<n><n>#### Rationales No 3: "The Mr Manish is looking forward to more than 10 question" (first line), This statement can't be proved correctly.<n><n>### Sample Response 1: The company

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The sentence asks for a suitable noun to describe the complexity of the machine. <n>2. The first option, 'box', is not suitable because although a box could possibly contain complex things, it is not complex in itself.<n>3. The second option, 'apparatus', refers to a complex piece of equipment or machinery, making it a suitable choice.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:The mother was worried about all the spills, so she bought a rug for under the what? Choices:  A: linen closet B: kitchen C: on the space heater D: fabric store E: bedroom<n><n>### Response:		<n>B: kitchen<n><n>### Rationales: 1.. The term "belong" means "to be used in an appropriate manner or place". So, option A: linen closets is incorrect because it does not mean an appropriate place, it could mean any closet, as long as it's a place to store the linen.<n>2. Option B: the kitchen is the appropriate place where we should put them. The term "them" can refer to the cloths.<n>The term "them" here represents cloths. <n>3. So, the answer to the question must be B: kitchen.<n>4. It is followed by option C: on the space. This doesn't make any sense because the space heater is not a place to hang things.<n>5. In option D: fabric store, we have similar language so, the same logic applies.<n>6. Option E: bedroom does not make sense because "bedroom" is inappropriate.<n>7. Finally the right answer is B: kitchen.<n>Answer: B kitchen<n>

Choices:    A: something B: people C: things D: no one E: somebody<n>Rationales:1. "It’s good to..." means that we should be happy that we see something.  <n>2. 'See' is the subject and'something' is its complement. The speaker is describing the subject and there is no such word ‘something’ in the sentence.<n>The only answer that matches the structure is ‘see people or things’ and no. The city is Tromsø.<n><n>### Justification:<n>Input: "This city in Northern Norway..." refers that the city exists in Northern Norway. "filled with things to do..." refers that the city is filled with things to do like Polarrunning, which could be a half-marathon.<n>"and located inside the middle of the Northern Lights oval, which city..." refers that the city name is contained in the middle of the oval. Finally, "... is located in the Polarrunning Tromsø." The city was found in the middle of the Polarrunning Tørsø, and that the city was located in Tromsø.

"Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Choices:  A: believe in god B: pay bills C: group together D: enjoy themselves E: face each other<n><n>### Response:		<n>The sentence states that people need to find ways of coming together, implying that there are ways to meet with other people. The third option, 'group together' is an activity or action that people perform, as opposed to a state or position. To meet with other people, there has to be an environment, so 'place' or 'location' is more suitable options. The first option, "believe in god" describes a state of having faith in god. While that can be an important way to meet people, it’s not about meeting each other as much as about faith and religion. The sentences talks about finding ways to come together, so something related to people meeting each other is more required. The second option, pay bills, doesn't reflect meeting each other. The fourth option, "enjoy themselves" implies that the people are already together, which isn't what the sentence asks for. 'Face each other', the last option, is another action or activity, which doesn't fit the question either. <n><n>The only option that describes a state of people meeting and not being an action or activity, is 'place'. It's the most suitable word for the answer because meeting people can't depend on an action or activity. It needs a location, so the answer is E: place.

Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What does exercising immediately lead to? Choices:  A: relaxation B: exhaustion C: energetic D: become stronger E: use energy<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: relaxation <n><n>Directions: Input:The last man to cross the finish line is the? Choices:  winner A: loser B: race competitor C: athlete D: prize competitor E: run winner<n>Rationales: In the race scenario, the runners who finish last are usually not counted or considered as part of the competition. Since the finish line is the last place where someone can cross, the last one to cross is not a competitor of the race. So, he isn't a loser or participant of the race, and the correct answer cannot be options A: loser or B: race competitor.<n><n>Next, the question asks for the correct person to describe the winner of the race scenario. This is usually the runner who passed the finish line first. He is also the athlete that took first place in the race competition. Therefore the option C: athlete is correct.<n>Similarly, if there were several runners crossing the finish line at the same time, we would have the option of race competitors, and the one that finished first in terms of time would also be counted as winner of the race in terms of position. So, the answer can't be E: prize competitor.<n>The correct answer therefore is athlete as it is the most suitable choice.<n><n>### Input<n>The last man to cross<n><n>### Response<n>Athlete<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The sentence asks for a suitable noun to describe the complexity of the machine. <n>2. The first option, 'box', is not suitable because although a box could possibly contain complex things, it is not complex in itself.<n>3. The second option, 'apparatus', refers to a complex piece of equipment or machinery, making it a suitable choice.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. Hence, the answer is B: apparatus.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Rationales: 1. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:There is a lot of sugar in what food that fits in your hand? Choices:  A: cupboard B: chocolate C: coffee D: candy bar E: soda pop<n><n>### Response:		<n>There is a lot of energy in a chocolate bar.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. The first word in the instruction is "there is a lot of" so we begin with the first letter "T" and move to the last letter "L" so the possible answer choices become TLLE and then LLE, the latter of which matches "a lot of sugar in what" perfectly.<n>2. The first letter after "a lot of" is an "L," so the next possible answer choice that fits is "L" meaning "candy bar" is the most likely answer.<n>3. However, we also look at the word "lot" and see if it's present in any other choice. The word "lot" is in the choices "a lot of sugar", so that's a better word match.<n>4. Next we look for another word match. We see the word "in" in the question, and the choice for "sugar" has it in the same spot, making that a better word match. Then we see the rest of the question and we figure out which choice fits, giving us "C" or candy bar.<n><n>## Difficult Words<n><n>| Word | Definition | Frequency-Word-count |<n>|:-:|:-:|:-:-:||<n>| A lot |  |  |<n>| chocolate |  |  | <n>| sugar |  |  |

Choices:  A: hear crowd go mad B: working hard C: clap D: reproduce E: celebrate<n><n>### Response:		C: clap<n>Clap: verb, “to make a loud noise by clapping the hands”<n><n>### Definition:An invitation is a request to do something with specific information that supports it.<n>### Definition:A question is asked to get information.<n><n>### Exercises:<n>The question is about the definition of a question versus an invitation. I am assuming that you found the definition above correct and accurate. If not, then the answer could be A, C, D. <n>If you did find the definition correct and accurate, then you could find the answer in choices A, C, D, and F or E. If you did not find the definition of an invitation correct and accurate then the answer to F could be A or D. 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The sentence asks for a suitable noun to describe the complexity of the machine. <n>2. The first option, 'box', is not suitable because although a box could possibly contain complex things, it is not complex in itself.<n>3. The second option, 'apparatus', refers to a complex piece of equipment or machinery, making it a suitable choice.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. Hence, the answer is B: apparatus.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Rationales: 1. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:We want to try some new barbecue sauces, where should we buy some? Choices:  A: detroit B: australia C: michigan park D: cafe E: retail store<n><n>### Response:		Answer: B: Australia<n><n>### Input : We are planning a picnic in the city park. We need to buy food, drinks, and games. Where should we buy them? Choices: <n>A: shopping mall B: grocery store C: restaurant D: fast food E: convenience store<n><n>### **Output : Choice A: shopping mall**<n><n>### **Input :** I saw a movie by the sea. Where was I when I saw the movie?<n>**Answer :** C: at the beach.<n><n>### **Instruction :** Identify the pronoun that best completes the sentence.<n><n>### My best friend lives in a small town.<n>Which of the following pronouns can replace the underlined pronoun?<n>A) her<n>B) him<n>C) me<n>D) she<n>E) them<n><n>### Which one of the following pronoun may be used to replace which?<n>My best friend lives in a big city. A) a B) that C) what D) who E) whom f) any other pronoun<n><n>### Instructions:Choose the pronoun that completes each sentence. Check all choices that apply. Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The sentence asks for a suitable noun to describe the complexity of the machine. <n>2. The first option, 'box', is not suitable because although a box could possibly contain complex things, it is not complex in itself.<n>3. The second option, 'apparatus', refers to a complex piece of equipment or machinery, making it a suitable choice.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. Hence, the answer is B: apparatus.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Rationales: 1. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What body of water is typically shallow water? Choices:  A: lake B: aquariums C: swimming pool D: pond E: childrens pools<n><n>### Response:		B: aquariums<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question based on the information presented above.<n>### Demonstraion:<n>### Input:Choose the correct answer. What should you do first with freshly bought vegetables? Choices: A : place in a fresh water B : cut the vegetables C : cut the vegetables D : wash the vegetables E : put in the fridge F : put in a salad bowl<n><n>### Response:(A) Place in a fresh water<n>### Demonstatement:<n>### Input:"Place in a the vegetables in fresh water" means to put the vegetables in fresh, clean water that has been purified.<n>### Choice A indicates that the vegetables are placed in clean water.<n>### Choices B, C and D have been eliminated because the word vegetables is plural, which does not match with the singular form wash. Choice F: the vegetables in salad bowl is not correct because the vegetables that had been bought had not been put in salad bowls. Therefore, answer A is correct.<n> Answer: (A): Place in a fresh water.

Choices:  A: walmart B: loft C: house D: home depot E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Inputs:<n>1. "The man needed to buy a flooring."<n>2. "He wanted to buy it from a shop that sold furnishings."<n>3. "He went to a house."<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. "He went to the house." = "He went back to the house."<n>2. "I will take the house." = "I will take him to the house."<n>3. "I will go back to the house." = I will come back to the house." ("He went to a house. He bought something at the house. He decided to return to the house.")<n>4. Since the man needed to buy a floor he needed a house to go in.<n>5. But the man decided to go to the house. So he found what he needed at the house.<n>6. "House"= a room in which people live.<n>7. Therefore the answer is D: home.<n><n>### Answer:<n>D: home<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: You bought a new computer. Choices A: the monitor B: the mouse C: the keyboard D: the screen E: the mousepad F: the computer G: the computer monitor H: the computer screen I: the printer J: the computer keyboard J: the mouse<n>Rationales for each of the choices:<n><n>1. The main function of a computer is not to have a mouse.<n>2. It's to use software / access information.<n>3. You can't even turn it off without the mouse.<n>4. Because the mouse doesn't have any other purpose.<n>5. The main functions of a computer are the monitor, the mouse, the keyboard and the screen.<n>6. Choice C: the keyboard is correct because the monitor is correct <n>7. and you have to use these things with the mouse and the screen on.<n>8. Choice A: the monitor is incorrect because there would be no information without input device.<n>9. Choice G: the computer monitor is incorrect because you can't use the computer if the monitor is not there.<n>10. Choice J: the computer mouse is incorrect because you need it in order to use the computer.<n>11. Choice I: the printer is incorrect because a printer is a peripheral device that is not necessary when running a computer.

Choices:  A.Burn, B: Fire, C: Smoke, D: Burn, E: smell smoke<n>###  <n>### Demonstraion:<n>Input: The fire is an unpleasant smell when something is burning or something is very hot. Choice: A: Burn, B: ____, C: Smoke, <n>D: ____, E: Burn<n><n><n>Rationales:1. The sentence shows that the fire creates a "burned smell".<n>2. The term "burned smell" is not an "unpleasant smell", rather, it is an "unpleasant sound".<n>3. Therefore, the only correct option that reflects this meaning is A: Burn.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. Hence, the answer is B: apparatus.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Rationales: 1. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What could happen to you after you see some beautiful clouds above you? Choices:  A: plain B: cold C: dull D: bad E: wet<n><n>### Response:		<n>Option: D<n>Rationales: Choice: A = plain = nothing happens after seeing (beautiful clouds)<n>Choice: B = Cold = it could happen to you after cold/rainy day<n>Choice: C = dull = it could happen to make you bored during cold/rainy weather time<n>Choice: E = wet = it means after heavy rain, could be very hot<n>Choice: D = Bad = it happens when you do something bad and it could be a good or bad thing<n>Answer: D: Bad<br />Rationale: <br />Choices: A: plain= nothing happens<br />B: cold= you could get cold/rainy day<br />C: dull= you could be bored during cold/ rainy weather<br />D: bad= you could do bad thing and good thing<br />E: wet= you could do bad and good thing<n><n>### Input 1:Where do you usually find your brother?<n>Input 2:What do you do when you reach a traffic light?<n>Input 3:How do you manage to stay fit?<n>Input 4:What should you do if you want to be a professional chef?<n><n>### Response<n>Input 1: I find my brother usually at home.<n>input 2: When I reach a traffic light, I wait until the light turns green before I can cross the street.<n>input 3: I eat healthy foods and do regular exercise.<n>input 4: To be a professional chef, I need to learn about all aspects of the work. I study and practice hard for a long time.<n><n>### Input<n>A: What's the weather like outside? It didn't matter.   He didn't heave anything to put it on, and he lacked the what to balance it? Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		<n>In this question, the key words, "what", "he didn't", "and" are the keys for a specific answer. <n>After the prepositional phrase, he should get an article.  the "he" refers to the the man that did the action.<n>We put an article to help the reader know we are going to identify noun that will substitute the words "what" in this sentence.<n><n>**Option D**<n>> He diden't have (whom) the skill to balance it on.<n>**Option C**<n>> He didn't have (whomm) the hands to balance it on. (Wrong pronoun used).<n>**Option B**<n>> He didn’t have (how) the tenacity to balance it on (Wrong pronoun).<n>**Option A**<n>> He didn (how) the tenansce to balance it on (The article is not given).<n>**Option E**<n>> He didn"t (how) the strength to balance it on (This is an action verb not a noun).<n>The correct answer is:  D: skill<n>

Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n><n>### Response:		The sentence is asking what affected the school's efforts to change. Hence, the sentence is asking 'why'. Therefore, we can start looking for the 'why' clause. Since we are looking for 'why', the 'effort the school had made to changing' is the subject. The answer can only logically follow the subject. Looking at the options, 'ignore' is not logical since ignoring efforts is not why we would not change. 'Enforce' doesn't work since this answer choice doesn't explain why. 'Authoritarian', 'yerll at', and 'avoid' do not belong in a multiple choice question, they're phrases and not a choice. The last choice is 'yell at'. The 'yell at' explanation follows the logical flow of the sentence. I'm pretty sure. Hence, the answer to the question is 'B'. <n>Answer: B: yell at<n><n>### Input : You can't do it. So why try? Choices:  Choices: A: You will try again B: You will never try again C: You might fail<n><n>### Response : You can't, so why try. So, we can eliminate B. 'You might fail' does not match the logical flow of the question - so, it can be eliminated. What's left is A: You will try. So the answer is A. <n>Answer: A: You will fail<n><n>### Input - The two bosses were locked in a confrontation that the junior staff had to what? Choices : (A) Listen to (B) Hear (C) Overhear (D) Intercept (E) Witness (F) Hear about<n><n>###  Response - The sentence is asking the staff how they learned of the two bosses's confrontation and that it was a conflict. The options do not make sense in relation to this sentence. (Listen to, overhear, witness, and hear) are actions that the staff is doing to learn about the fight - not necessarily a direct result of the fight. I think the correct answer is "D" intercept, which fits the role of a junior member of staff as a direct result of the two boss's argument.<n>Answer: D: Intercept<n><n>### Input- A very long day is coming to what? The answer that we are looking for is inkwell.<n>The word ‘pen’ in the sentence could be replaced with any pronoun. This sentence can be rephrased to ask “What did flop-pen-washer-soaker people use to absorb ink?” The pronoun in the place of ‘pen’ must be an object. The sentence becomes clearer once the pronoun is added to the picture of the sentence. The sentence now reads as “Who used to soak up ink that fell in your flop-pen-soaker?” The question refers to the tool used to soak up extra ink from a pen. What do people use to absord extra ink from a floop pen. Thus, if we replace ‘pen’ with the pronoun ‘it’ in the original sentence, the sentence becomes “What do people use to soak up in extra ink from an item?” The word ‘item’ will refer to a tool that can absorb ink. The item that we can use to absorb inks extra ink from the floop pen can be an inkwell. The correct answer will be C: inkwell <n>Answer: C:inkwell<n><n>### Instructions: <n>Write a statement that describes the situation and presents a situation that is common in our daily lives<n><n>### Input<n>What is the main advantage of digital photography? The sentence specifies that Johnny sat on a bench in a state park.<n><n>### In 2021, the United States Supreme Court case Fulton v. Philadelphia, which addressed whether or not laws or regulations that prohibited the provision of foster care by faith-based agencies if they didn’t abide by the city or state’s nondiscrimination in foster and adoption requirements (also known as non-discrimination requirements), ruled that the City of Philadelphia (1) had to modify their policy  regarding the provision of foster services to faith‐based agencies, including those that only serve LGBTQ individuals;(2) had to follow that policy for all faith‐based agencies equally, and (3) had to allow the faith‐based agencies to provide services on a case-by-case basis, without the City of Philadelphia’s involvement, which meant that they had to allow faith-based agencies the ability to follow their faith. <n><n>## Instructions:Read the passage, and complete the summary by typing your answer in the blank boxes. In your summary, refer back to the information in the original text about how the Supreme Court ruled, what the City of Philadelphia had to do, and why the faith-based agencies had to provide services for all individuals. Your summary must include a sentence explaining how each item listed in  applies to the larger context. <n><n>## Summary:In 2021 the United States Supreme Court issued a decision in the case of Fulton v. City of Philadelphia which said that the City of Philadelphia had wrongfully discriminated against faith-based agencies in the case which involves foster and adoption servces. According to the United States Supreme Court, the case was that Catholic Social Services of the Archdiocese of Philadelphia did not need to make foster care placements outside of the same-sex coupled homes. The Philadelphia Department of Human Services also restricted faith-based organizations' services, from Catholic Social Services' foster care services, and the Philadelphia Department of Human Services was supposed to change its policies by following equal policies for all faith-based agencies and allowing the faith-based agency to provide services without involving the city of Philadelphia in the process. 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The sentence asks for a suitable noun to describe the complexity of the machine. <n>2. The first option, 'box', is not suitable because although a box could possibly contain complex things, it is not complex in itself.<n>3. The second option, 'apparatus', refers to a complex piece of equipment or machinery, making it a suitable choice.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. Hence, the answer is B: apparatus.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Rationales: 1. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What is it called when you slowly cook using a grill? Choices:  A: backyard B: restaurant C: crockpot D: neighbor's house E: barbeque<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct response is D:barbeque<n><n>Rationale: When the question asked you what is it called, it's the question you need to answer which is D: barbeque <n><n>### Input :<n>Who is watching over the city after dark? Choices: A: firefighters B: dog catchers C: police officers D: dog catchers E: firefighters<n><n>### Answer:<n>The answer is D: police officer<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The response that needs to be entered in this task is D: police officers <n><n>### In an instruction:<n><n>### Response<n>### Demonstion<n><n>### Detailed Answers<n>1. The instructions will always have a what will, who will, when will, where to do the task, as well as how to do it<n>2. I need to do my homework before I go to school everyday.<n>3. The instructions give the student tasks, and they give students hints on how to answer these tasks. <n><n><n>

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The sentence asks for a suitable noun to describe the complexity of the machine. <n>2. The first option, 'box', is not suitable because although a box could possibly contain complex things, it is not complex in itself.<n>3. The second option, 'apparatus', refers to a complex piece of equipment or machinery, making it a suitable choice.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. Hence, the answer is B: apparatus.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Rationales: 1. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What does playing soccer for a long time lead to? Choices:  A: excitement B: fatigue C: anger D: hurting E: getting tired<n><n>### Response:		The first thing a person does when he plays for a long time is getting __________. Choices:  A B: tired C: excited D: hurting E fatigued<n><n>### Rationale: The instruction specifies a verb that refers to the consequence of the action of playing for a long time.<n><n>### Choice 4: C: <n>Explanation: Though 'getting tired' would appear to be the correct answer, based on the information the question provides, it is not correct. <n><n>### Explanation: While 'getting tired' is incorrect as it is simply the result in which we have an answer, the question specifically asks for a noun, meaning an action verb is necessary. <n>Thus, we should answer with "excited", which is a correct noun. <n><n>## Summary:<n>* Use the verb "get" when the main content word is a noun that refers to a consequence of an action.<n>* Don't use the verb "get" with "for" as the main content word because for then becomes a verb phrase.<n>* In the context of a yes/no question, the answer is a noun.<n>

Choices:  A: the reward money B: hurt feelings C: being found out D: problems E: trouble<n><n>### Response:		The correct response is D: problems.<n>Sentence Meaning<n>: Sentence is wrong about the second question, but Sean worried about what.<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>* The first option 'body' means Sean lying about the body or the body of the person in the lake. <n>* The second option'reward money' means the amount of money offered for informing the right person about someone's whereabouts.<n>* The third option 'being found out' means disclosing someone's whereabout he is or has been hiding.<n>* The fourth option 'what hurt feelings' means feelings of those who were hurt.<n>* The fifth option 'his problems' means his own problems.<n>That's why we can figure out the complete sentence as 'he worried about what problems he would encounter if' <n><n>* The correct answer is D: problems is Sean worried about in the sentence.<n><n>### Input : How did we get that video?  Choices:  A : A robot B: Machine C: It fell from the sky D: The wind blew it<n>Rationales:<n>* Option A:<n>Robots are not that small<n>* Option B:<n>The machine does not fall in the sky<n>* Option C: <n>The wind doesn't have any color so can't be used<n>* Option D: <n>The wind itself didn't carry the tape but probably something else in the air carried it<n><n>## Question 3:<n>Input :  It was a terrible storm. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Joe suffered many consequences from stabbing a stranger to death.   Among them, the family of the victim did something to him. What was that? Choices:  A: knife wounds B: buy a gun C: bleeding D: jail time E: law suit<n><n>### Response:		The response that best completes the task will demonstrate an understanding of the question and a solid command of the language required. Your response should begin with the first sentence in which you paraphrase and respond to the prompt.<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>1. The prompt tells us that there are several consequences that a certain action can have on the person who did the action. The prompt then focuses us on the consequences of a single event.<n>2. Here we see this through the phrasing at the start: "of stabbing a stranger..." In this phrase, the stabbing is the action, and the stranger is the result, the consequence.<n>3. Once we know that the action is a stranger, the phrase that comes after "the family of the victim did... is to refer to a specific action. <n><n>4. "Did something" sounds ambiguous because it could refer to either the family or to the victim. However, the prompt then narrows down the choice to the family. We can't just decide to use "victim's family" either, as it would result in two actions occurring, which is not what the sentence wants<n>5. We can notice this because the question marks the two choices left and the answer is in the question itself: "... The family..." This means the family took an action.<n>6. The choices for did something are as follows: "... bleeding." We don't have family and victim all together as one action. The victim can't bleed... but the family can.<n>7. Answer A: bleeding is the right choice.<n>8. Answer: A: bleeding<n><n>### Input 1 : The students who didn't study passed by the class without knowing anything about the test. Choices:  A. passed by without knowing anything B. passed by not knowing anything C. passed by without knowing everything D. passed by knowing nothing E. pass by knowing nothing.<n><n>Rationals: 1. The task doesn't ask for the meaning of the sentence. It asks for the meaning of the phrase "without knowing anything about the test". <n>2. "Didn't study" does not indicate that the students passed by. It indicates that they didn't study and that there are still other students who have studied for the test. They don't know anything about the test so that's why they don't study. But who

Choices:  A: pine tree B: open country C: in washington D: wildlife refuge E: sky<n><n>### Response:		Bald eagles make their nests in open country, like mount ransome in washington.<n><n>### Explanation:The correct choice will fit in the sentence grammatically, as well as making sense logically.<n><n>The question is asking where a bald eagle would feel safe, and the best answer is open country.<n><n>The first word in the sentence is 'Where'. 'Where' is an interrogative word, so the rest of the sentence will be a question, i.e. a question beginning with 'Where'. We then look for any preposition at the start of the sentence. In this case, there are none, so there is no need to use 'Where'. Instead, we use 'in', which becomes the subject of the sentence, followed by 'w' for the verb 'is'.<n><n>We then look at the list of answers, and decide that the only answer that makes sense and fits into the context of the sentence is 'open country'.<n><n>### Input : __________________<n><n>### Input 2 : __________________<n>

You would gather information while chatting with friends. If you were looking to kill boredom you would likely play a game or do something productive.<n>2. By the sentence structure (the phrase "is likely hoping to accomplish") that says there is more than one option so D is incorrect<n>3.  We can rule out A: gathering of informat. since there is a question mark that shows that is not necessarily going to be the answer<n>4. B: communication is only an option if you are bored and not talking to friends or family, so it isn't the answer.<n>5. If you are chatting with friends you are most likely trying to socialise with them or be closer friends<n>6. C, 'feel relaxed', would be an option if you were with friends trying to help you get over a hard day, or something<n>7. E,'social bonds', would be the main answer, but can also be used as a sub answer<n>### Answer: (write your answer here)<n>

Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:The sensor would just the distance then set off an alarm, the installation expert explained it was called a what kind of sensor? Choices:  A: near B: closeness C: here D: proximity E: this<n><n>### Response:		<n>The sensor would just the (distance), then set off an alarm. The installation expert explained it was a (proximity) sensor. <n><n>### Instrument: Answer the following multiple choice question from the options.<n><n>### Response::(answer)A: Proximity sensor as that is the only one that fits in the sentence.<n><n>A: Proximity<n>B: Near<n>C: Closeness<n>D: Here<n>E: this<n>### Explanation:This question can be answered by just looking at the options and finding out that "Proximity" is the only option that fits in the sentence as "Proximity" has the same meaning as of the word in the example.<n><n>### Extra Credit Exercise:<n><n>### Instructor: What time has your meeting been set? Choices: <n><n>### Demostration:<n>- A: 11:59 B: 1:59 C: 2:19 D: 4:19 <n><n>Instructor response:<n><n>In the end "1:59" fits perfectly in the sentence if we exclude "11:59" and the numbers after "11:5" are after the comma because in the English language the numbers in a date or time should be split. so the correct answer is C : 2:19.<n><n>### Final Response<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The sentence asks for a suitable noun to describe the complexity of the machine. <n>2. The first option, 'box', is not suitable because although a box could possibly contain complex things, it is not complex in itself.<n>3. The second option, 'apparatus', refers to a complex piece of equipment or machinery, making it a suitable choice.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. Hence, the answer is B: apparatus.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Rationales: 1. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people doing jumping jacks? Choices:  A: military base B: opera C: water fountain D: bus stop E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n>Because the answer involves people, this isn't a good option. And because "doing jumping jacks" is only performed during exercise, option A: Military Base wouldn't be the best answer. So the correct answer would be C: opera.<n><n>### Input:(There is) a lake in North Carolina. Choices:  A. No lake in North Carolina B: A lot of cactus in North Carolina C: 70's era in North Carolina D: not a lot of ozone in North Carolina E: no fish in North Carolina<n><n>### Response:-<n>This question was about whether North Carolina has a lake (which it does), so this answer isn't an option. But since the question didn't specify which lake, A. No lake in north Carolina is probably the correct answer because it's not a correct answer to question of if North Carolina has a lake or not.<n><n>### Response to answer<n>1. Lake: a large body of water surrounded by land.<n>2. Choice A doesn't make sense because North Carolina definitely has a lake, and they would certainly know that. "There is no lake" is an obvious lie, so they would never answer with that.<n>3. Choice B is also not a logical response because North Carolina does not and has not had anything to do with cactus.<n>4. Choice C is incorrect because it is in the wrong tense. It would be correct to say "70's era", but it should not be, "70's ERA in North Carolina".<n>5. Choice D is incorrect because although it's a "common knowledge" fact that a lot of ozone is in North Carolina, it is not correct because the person is specifically asking if there is a lake in North Carolina, not if there is a lot of ozone there.<n>6. Choice E is incorrect because it's possible North Carolina does not have fish. It is in fact not known if North Carolina has fish or not, so this option would technically be correct, though very unlikely.<n>7. Therefore A. No lake in N. Carolina is the correct answer<n><n>### Instructions:Read the following text to answer the question.<n><n>## The new restaurant was built in a remote town. It was not an easy choice to make when building the new restaurant, because there were no roads, water,

Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. Choices:  A: music store B: dance hall C: orchestra D: symphony E: tennessee<n><n>### Response:		D: Symphony<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>1. "Where is there" means that we are looking for a place, not for something like "is playing" or "will be played". That is, the answer must be a place.<n>2. "Fiddle playing" is an act, not a place, so it won't suit the phrase "usually a".<n>3. "Music store" is also an act, and is something people look for in a music store.<n>4. "Dance hall" is a place, but "fiddle playing", is not playing, and a fiddle is only an instrument.<n>5. "Orchestra" is a place, although people with a fiddle in the orchestra may or may not be playing it.<n>6. "Symphony" is probably what you think of when you think of a symphony orchestra.<n>7. Therefore the answer is B: dancehall.<n><n>### Input where is the piano located?<n><n>

A machine that is simple is easy to explain on the contrast the machine was quite and this complex implies that the machine would be deep in its operations. Machine is an inanimate object that does not possess the ability to think, so the deepness in this machine can only be shown by its operations and weaker than other machines so it is quite a machine to beholds.<n><n>### Feedback: This example describes how to find the correct choice for multiple choice questions. <n>### Difficulty: [Hard]<n>### Skill: [Language]<n>### Feedforward:<n>Congratulations! Choices:  "A: Train "B: No "C: Money "D: Driver "E: Engine<n>Rationales: A,B,C,D,E are not suitable. <n>E is closest.<n>Rationales: The sentence is asking about the reason for the fast movement of the train. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The sentence asks for a suitable noun to describe the complexity of the machine. <n>2. The first option, 'box', is not suitable because although a box could possibly contain complex things, it is not complex in itself.<n>3. The second option, 'apparatus', refers to a complex piece of equipment or machinery, making it a suitable choice.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. Hence, the answer is B: apparatus.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Rationales: 1. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:The student needed to  get some new pencils, where did he go? Choices:  A: store B: classroom C: backpack D: cabinet E: teacher<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The student needed to get some new pencills, where did he go? Store would be the answer.<n><n>Because, he would have gone to get some new pens. Hence, store would be the answer.

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The sentence asks for a suitable noun to describe the complexity of the machine. <n>2. The first option, 'box', is not suitable because although a box could possibly contain complex things, it is not complex in itself.<n>3. The second option, 'apparatus', refers to a complex piece of equipment or machinery, making it a suitable choice.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. Hence, the answer is B: apparatus.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Rationales: 1. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Where can meat last a long time? Choices A: bus, B: car, C: by foot, D: by train.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Input: How were you going to make dinner? Rationales: 1 There is only one question mark so this is an interrogative sentence ( a question ). <n>2 This is not an imperative sentence. <n><n>Answer: A: by train.<n>

The first option, 'box', is not suitable because although a box could possibly contain complex things, it is not complex in itself.<n>3. The second option, 'apparatus', refers to a complex piece of equipment or machinery, making it a suitable choice.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:The teacher told all the students that listening was key, it was the main way they would gain what? Choices:  A: empathy B: anxiety C: knowlege D: falling down E: hear things<n><n>### Response:		<n>* A: The answer requires the teacher to tell all the students that listening is the main way they would achieve "knowledge.". However, "empathy" is a mental state. "Anxiety" is a emotion. "Knowledge" and "being" "falling down" are not the same thing as knowledge. Finally "hear things" does not answer the question as hearing things is just a form of listening.<n>* B: "Anxiety" refers to a condition, which can happen without listening. "Falling down" is not an actionable verb.<n>* C: "Knowledge" doesn't refer to just learning, but instead could mean everything one has learn about something or even the act of knowing itself. It can't be the main way "knowledge" would be acquired. Also, "knowledge" is a noun.<n>* D: "Hearing things" is an action, it requires the listeners to hear things.<n>* E: "Empathy" again is a mental state.<n><n>The right answer is C: knowledge<n><n><n>### Instructions:Read the text, then answer the questions. In the text, there are 7 mistakes. If possible, type your answer in the comments section (ex. I think it should have said “The book is not only a guide book but also a good read”. Write a response that completes the description properly using "really"<n>2. Write a response that doesn't use "really" in a sentence.<n><n>#### Guidance:<n>1.  Really is a very common adverb. We use the word really when we want to emphasize a point or when we want to say something that may not be completely true. A good replacement for the word really is definitely or of course.<n>2.  You need to create a sentence to complete the description.<n><n><n><n><n>## CTA (Challenge, Task, Action)<n><n>Challenge<n><n>Write a sentence that correctly complements the description using the word really. Challenge the student to come up with appropriate context and to create a sentence.<n><n>Task<n><n>Write 3-5 sentences. Task the student to write a response.<n><n>Action<n><n>Student’s responses.<n><n><n><n>

The first option, 'box', is not suitable because although a box could possibly contain complex things, it is not complex in itself.<n>3. The second option, 'apparatus', refers to a complex piece of equipment or machinery, making it a suitable choice.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. Hence, the answer is B: apparatus.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Rationales: 1. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. Hence, the answer is B: apparatus.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Rationales: 1. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:Who is likely yo have a caring heart? Choices:  A: person B: species C: artichoke D: all mammals E: live animal<n><n>### Response:		A: person<n><n>Input: Which of the following should be pluralized to have a plural form? Choices:  N: the people I work for B: the people C: these people D: these ones E: them<n>Rationales: To answer this question you must know what is singular and what is plural.<n>1. The first choice, N: the people I  work for, is a complete noun phrase. 'people I work for' is a compound noun while 'the people I work for' is not compound noun.<n>2. The second choice, B: the people, is the plural form of the singular noun, 'people'. So, it is the complete version.<n>3. The third option, C: these people,  is a complete noun, while 'these people' is not a noun.<n>4. The fourth choice, D: these  ones, is a noun of a certain type. But it's not a complete one, so, it can't function as the 'completely noun' in the context.<n>5. The last option, E: them, is not a definite noun, it's an indefinite pronoun.<n>6. Hence, the correct choice is B: the people.<n>Answer: B, the people<n><n>Input: What is a good sentence for a thesis statement? Choices: 1. The thesis was an interesting and worthwhile experience. 2. This thesis was an interesting, worthwhile experience. 3. The thesis was a wonderful, thoughtful experience. 4. The thesis was just an average idea. 5. The thesis was awesome.<n>Answer: A: The thesis was an  interesting and worthwhile experience<n><n><n>### Instructions: Write a sentence based on a clue and the context.<n><n>### Input : Which of the following sentences is correct? A: I  have a great  and  amazing  dog. B: I have a great and amazing dog. C: A great and  amazing  do I have. D: I have a great  and amazing  dog.<n><n>### Response  : I have a  great  and  amazin dog.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The sentence asks for a suitable noun to describe the complexity of the machine. <n>2. The first option, 'box', is not suitable because although a box could possibly contain complex things, it is not complex in itself.<n>3. The second option, 'apparatus', refers to a complex piece of equipment or machinery, making it a suitable choice.<n>4. The term 'appliance', the third option, is generally used to refer to devices that perform specific tasks, usually in a household setting, but it doesn’t necessarily imply complexity.<n>5. 'Wash dishes', the fourth choice, is a verb phrase and doesn't fit the structure of the sentence.<n>6. The last option, 'implement', is used to refer to tools or instruments that are meant for a particular purpose, but it doesn’t necessarily denote complexity.<n>7. Therefore, the only choice that fits the sentence correctly and reflects the complexity of the machine is 'apparatus'. <n>8. Hence, the answer is B: apparatus.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>Input: Where do you get petrol? Choices:  A: burn hot B: fuel tank C: burn hot D: car E: gas station<n>Rationales: 1. "Where" initially tells us that the answer requires a location.<n>2. The question is basically asking where petrol is usually acquired.<n>3. So, it is a place where petrol is typically available.<n>4. We can immediately rule out option A: burn hot and option C: burn hot, as they are not locations.<n>5. Next we check option B: fuel tank. Though a fuel tank does contain petrol, it’s not a place where you can get petrol. So, this option doesn't answer the question.<n>6. Looking at option D: car. We put petrol in the car, but we do not get petrol from a car. So, this option can’t answer the question either.<n>7. Finally, we look at option E: gas station. A gas station is indeed a location where we go to get petrol.<n>8. Therefore, the answer is E: gas station.<n>Answer: E: gas station<n><n>### Input:What will happen to skin pinched in something? Choices:  A: feel cold B: feel pressure C: feel bumpy D: itches E: feel clammy<n><n>### Response:		skin will feel cold and itches<n>

"Deep grass" is also a noun phrase and it is also an answer for the question "what". The sentence says "the snake hiding deep in the tall grass".<n>6. Choices:  A: mail box B: suitcase C: front door D: bowl E: post office<n><n>### Response:		Letters are sometimes hand-delivered through a mailbox. <n><n>### Discussion:<n><n>This could also just be:  <n>“Letters are sometimes delivered hand-delivered...”  <n>or <n>“Letters are usually delivered hand-deliver...”<n><n>Letters can also be delivered through a porch (like, with a mail box sitting on it), or through the mail carrier.<n><n>We are talking about letters in this sentence. So, a post office may take letters, but these days, usually when people want to send a letter, they send an email. Post offices may send emails, but are not in business to deliver letters.<n><n>If you are using “hand-delivered” in a sentence where the answer might be “mail” then probably you also need to include “through”.<n><n>For example:<n><n>When she found out her birthday gift was hand-delivered, she was surprised.<n><n>She may have found out through an online account. Or, by mail.<n><n>It’s a bit of a nuance. But it’s a nice one.<n><n>### Discord Link: https://discord.gg/8u5wKgjBvw<n>### Slack Link: https://tinyurl.com/y4bk7y2j
